questions.q: What is a proposition?
questions.explanation: A proposition must be a declarative statement that has a specific truth value (true or false).
options: A declarative sentence that is either true or false, but not both

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a proposition?
questions.explanation: Questions are not propositions because they do not affirm or deny anything and thus lack a truth value.
options: Cairo is the capital of Egypt

questions.q: What is the truth value of the proposition "2 + 3 = 5"?
questions.explanation: The mathematical statement is factually correct, so its truth value is True.

questions.q: Is "x + 3 = 7" a proposition?
questions.explanation: It is an open sentence (predicate). It is not a proposition until the variable 'x' is bound or assigned a value.
options: No, because it contains a variable
Yes, if x is assigned a value
Both B and C are correct

questions.q: What symbol is used to denote negation?
questions.explanation: The symbol ¬ (or sometimes ~) represents logical negation (NOT).

questions.q: If p is true, what is the truth value of ¬p?
questions.explanation: Negation flips the truth value. If p is True, ¬p is False.

questions.q: What does the symbol ∧ represent?
questions.explanation: The symbol ∧ represents the logical conjunction, equivalent to 'AND'.

questions.q: When is p ∧ q true?
questions.explanation: A conjunction is true if and only if both operands are true.
options: When at least one of p or q is true
When both p and q are true
When p is true or q is false
When both p and q are false

questions.q: What does the symbol ∨ represent?
questions.explanation: The symbol ∨ represents logical disjunction, equivalent to the inclusive 'OR'.

questions.q: When is p ∨ q true?
questions.explanation: A disjunction is true if at least one of the propositions is true.
options: When at least one of p or q is true

questions.q: What is the symbol for exclusive OR (XOR)?
questions.explanation: The symbol ⊕ represents exclusive OR, which is true only when inputs differ.

questions.q: When is p ⊕ q true?
questions.explanation: XOR is true only when the truth values of p and q are different (one true, one false).
options: When at least one is true

questions.q: What is the symbol for conditional (implication)?
questions.explanation: The arrow → denotes a conditional statement (if... then).

questions.q: When is p → q false?
questions.explanation: An implication is only false when the hypothesis (p) is true but the conclusion (q) is false.
options: When p is true and q is false
When p is false and q is true

questions.q: What is the symbol for biconditional?
questions.explanation: The double arrow ↔ denotes a biconditional statement (if and only if).

questions.q: When is p ↔ q true?
questions.explanation: A biconditional is true when both statements share the same truth value (both true or both false).
options: When p and q have the same truth value
When p and q have different truth values

questions.q: What is the converse of p → q?
questions.explanation: The converse switches the hypothesis and the conclusion.

questions.q: What is the contrapositive of p → q?
questions.explanation: The contrapositive switches and negates both the hypothesis and the conclusion.

questions.q: What is the inverse of p → q?
questions.explanation: The inverse negates both the hypothesis and the conclusion without switching them.

questions.q: What is a tautology?
questions.explanation: A tautology is a compound proposition that is always true, regardless of the truth values of its variables.
options: A statement that is always false
A statement that is always true
A statement that can be either true or false
A statement with no truth value

questions.q: What is a contradiction?
questions.explanation: A contradiction is a compound proposition that is always false.
options: A statement that is always true
A statement that is always false
A statement with variable truth values
A statement that is neither true nor false

questions.q: What is p ∧ ¬p?
questions.explanation: A proposition cannot be both true and false at the same time, so this is always false (contradiction).

questions.q: What is p ∨ ¬p?
questions.explanation: This is the law of excluded middle; a statement is either true or false, so the disjunction is always true (tautology).

questions.q: In bit operations, what does 1 represent?
questions.explanation: In binary logic, 1 represents True and 0 represents False.

questions.q: What is the bitwise AND of 1 and 0?
questions.explanation: 1 AND 0 is equivalent to True AND False, which results in False (0).

questions.q: What is the bitwise OR of 1 and 0?
questions.explanation: 1 OR 0 is equivalent to True OR False, which results in True (1).

questions.q: What is the bitwise XOR of 1 and 1?
questions.explanation: XOR results in 0 (False) if the bits are the same.

questions.q: What is the universal quantifier symbol?
questions.explanation: The symbol ∀ (an inverted A) denotes 'for all' or 'for every'.

questions.q: What does ∀x P(x) mean?
questions.explanation: It asserts that the predicate P holds for every element x in the domain.
options: There exists an x such that P(x) is true
For all x, P(x) is true
P(x) is false for all x

questions.q: What is the existential quantifier symbol?
questions.explanation: The symbol ∃ (a reversed E) denotes 'there exists'.

questions.q: What does ∃x P(x) mean?
questions.explanation: It asserts that there is at least one element in the domain for which P is true.
options: For all x, P(x) is true
There exists at least one x such that P(x) is true
P(x) is false for all x

questions.q: Which logic gate corresponds to negation?
questions.explanation: A NOT gate inverts the input signal.

questions.q: Which logic gate corresponds to conjunction?
questions.explanation: An AND gate outputs high only if all inputs are high.

questions.q: Which logic gate corresponds to disjunction?
questions.explanation: An OR gate outputs high if at least one input is high.

questions.q: What is De Morgan's first law?
questions.explanation: De Morgan's laws describe how negation distributes over conjunctions and disjunctions. Both A and B represent these laws.

questions.q: According to De Morgan's laws, ¬(p ∧ q) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: The negation of a conjunction is the disjunction of the negations.

questions.q: According to De Morgan's laws, ¬(p ∨ q) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: The negation of a disjunction is the conjunction of the negations.

questions.q: What is the double negation law?
questions.explanation: Negating a negation returns the original truth value.

questions.q: What is the identity law for disjunction?
questions.explanation: Disjunction with False does not change the truth value of p.

questions.q: What is the domination law for conjunction?
questions.explanation: Conjunction with False always results in False, dominating the expression.

questions.q: What is p → q logically equivalent to?
questions.explanation: An implication is true if the hypothesis is false OR the conclusion is true.

questions.q: If p is "It is raining" and q is "The ground is wet," what is p → q?
questions.explanation: This is the standard conditional form 'If p, then q'.
options: It is raining and the ground is wet
If it is raining, then the ground is wet
It is raining or the ground is wet
The ground is wet if it is raining

questions.q: What is a counterexample for ∀x P(x)?
questions.explanation: A single instance where P(x) is false is sufficient to disprove a universal claim.
options: An element for which P(x) is true
An element for which P(x) is false
An element where P(x) is undefined

questions.q: What is the negation of ∀x P(x)?
questions.explanation: To negate 'all', you only need to show 'there exists at least one that is not'.

questions.q: What is the negation of ∃x P(x)?
questions.explanation: To negate 'there exists', you must show that 'for all, it is not true'.

questions.q: Which has higher precedence: ¬ or ∧?
questions.explanation: Negation binds more tightly than conjunction.

questions.q: What is the order of precedence for logical operators (highest to lowest)?
questions.explanation: Standard precedence is NOT, then AND, then OR, then Implication, then Biconditional.

questions.q: When translating "All students have studied calculus," if the domain is all students, which is correct?
questions.explanation: If the domain is already restricted to students, we simply say 'for all x, x studied calculus'.

questions.q: When translating "Some students have studied calculus," if the domain is all people, which is correct?
questions.explanation: For existential statements over a general domain, we use conjunction (AND) to specify the group and the property.

questions.q: What is the commutative law for conjunction?
questions.explanation: The order of operands in a conjunction does not matter.
